sections.title: Current, Voltage and Resistance
sections.content:
**Electric Current (I):**
• Flow of electric charge through a conductor
• SI unit: ampere (A)
• Measured using ammeter (connected in series)
• Direction: from positive to negative terminal (conventional current)

**Voltage/Potential Difference (V):**
• Energy transferred per unit charge
• SI unit: volt (V)
• Measured using voltmeter (connected in parallel)
• Battery/cell provides voltage

**Resistance (R):**
• Opposition to current flow
• SI unit: ohm (Ω)
• Factors affecting resistance:
  - Length (longer = more resistance)
  - Cross-sectional area (thicker = less resistance)
  - Material (conductivity)
  - Temperature
sections.content_zh:
**电流（I）：**
• 电荷通过导体的流动
• 国际单位：安培（A）
• 使用电流表测量（串联连接）
• 方向：从正极到负极（常规电流）

**电压/电位差（V）：**
• 每单位电荷传递的能量
• 国际单位：伏特（V）
• 使用电压表测量（并联连接）
• 电池/电池提供电压

**电阻（R）：**
• 对电流流动的阻力
• 国际单位：欧姆（Ω）
• 影响电阻的因素：
  - 长度（更长=更多电阻）
  - 横截面积（更粗=更少电阻）
  - 材料（导电性）
  - 温度

sections.title: Ohm's Law
sections.content:
**Ohm's Law:**
V = IR

Where:
• V = voltage (V)
• I = current (A)
• R = resistance (Ω)

**Key Points:**
• Voltage is directly proportional to current (at constant resistance)
• Current decreases as resistance increases (at constant voltage)
• A graph of V vs I gives a straight line for ohmic conductors

**Example:**
If a resistor has resistance 10Ω and current 2A flows through it:
V = IR = 2 × 10 = 20V

**Applications:**
• Calculating required resistance for circuits
• Determining safe current levels
• Designing electrical systems
sections.content_zh:
**欧姆定律：**
V = IR

其中：
• V = 电压（V）
• I = 电流（A）
• R = 电阻（Ω）

**要点：**
• 电压与电流成正比（恒定电阻时）
• 电流随电阻增加而减小（恒定电压时）
• 欧姆导体的V对I图给出直线

**示例：**
如果电阻器的电阻为10Ω，流过2A电流：
V = IR = 2 × 10 = 20V

**应用：**
• 计算电路所需电阻
• 确定安全电流水平
• 设计电气系统

sections.title: Series and Parallel Circuits
sections.content:
**Series Circuits:**
• Components connected in a single loop
• Same current through all components (I₁ = I₂ = I₃)
• Total voltage = sum of individual voltages (V_total = V₁ + V₂ + V₃)
• Total resistance = sum of individual resistances (R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃)
• If one component fails, circuit breaks

**Parallel Circuits:**
• Components connected across multiple branches
• Same voltage across all components (V₁ = V₂ = V₃ = V_total)
• Total current = sum of branch currents (I_total = I₁ + I₂ + I₃)
• Total resistance: 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃
• If one component fails, others continue working

**Home Wiring:**
Houses use parallel circuits so:
• All appliances get same voltage (230V in Singapore)
• Appliances work independently
• Can switch devices on/off without affecting others
sections.content_zh:
**串联电路：**
• 组件连接在单个回路中
• 所有组件的电流相同（I₁ = I₂ = I₃）
• 总电压=各个电压之和（V_总 = V₁ + V₂ + V₃）
• 总电阻=各个电阻之和（R_总 = R₁ + R₂ + R₃）
• 如果一个组件失效，电路断开

**并联电路：**
• 组件跨多个分支连接
• 所有组件的电压相同（V₁ = V₂ = V₃ = V_总）
• 总电流=分支电流之和（I_总 = I₁ + I₂ + I₃）
• 总电阻：1/R_总 = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃
• 如果一个组件失效，其他组件继续工作

**家庭布线：**
房屋使用并联电路，因此：
• 所有电器获得相同电压（新加坡为230V）
• 电器独立工作
• 可以打开/关闭设备而不影响其他设备

sections.title: Electrical Power and Energy
sections.content:
**Electrical Power (P):**
• Rate of energy transfer
• SI unit: watt (W) or kilowatt (kW)
• Formulas:
  - P = VI (power = voltage × current)
  - P = I²R (power = current² × resistance)
  - P = V²/R (power = voltage² / resistance)

**Electrical Energy (E):**
• Total energy consumed
• SI unit: joule (J) or kilowatt-hour (kWh)
• Formula: E = Pt (energy = power × time)
• 1 kWh = 3,600,000 J

**Example:**
A 2kW heater runs for 3 hours:
Energy = 2kW × 3h = 6 kWh

**Electricity Bills in Singapore:**
• Charged per kWh consumed
• SP Group charges about $0.30 per kWh
• Cost = Energy (kWh) × Tariff
• Energy-efficient appliances save money
sections.content_zh:
**电功率（P）：**
• 能量传递速率
• 国际单位：瓦特（W）或千瓦（kW）
• 公式：
  - P = VI（功率=电压×电流）
  - P = I²R（功率=电流²×电阻）
  - P = V²/R（功率=电压²/电阻）

**电能（E）：**
• 消耗的总能量
• 国际单位：焦耳（J）或千瓦时（kWh）
• 公式：E = Pt（能量=功率×时间）
• 1千瓦时 = 3,600,000焦耳

**示例：**
一个2千瓦的加热器运行3小时：
能量 = 2千瓦 × 3小时 = 6千瓦时

**新加坡的电费单：**
• 按消耗的千瓦时收费
• SP集团每千瓦时收费约$0.30
• 费用=能量（kWh）×电价
• 节能电器省钱

sections.title: What is the Electromagnetic Spectrum?
sections.content:
The electromagnetic (EM) spectrum is a continuous range of electromagnetic waves arranged according to their wavelength and frequency. All EM waves travel at the speed of light (3 × 10⁸ m/s) in a vacuum.

The spectrum includes (from longest wavelength to shortest):
• Radio waves - longest wavelength, lowest frequency
• Microwaves
• Infrared radiation
• Visible light (ROYGBIV)
• Ultraviolet radiation
• X-rays
• Gamma rays - shortest wavelength, highest frequency

Key relationship: As wavelength decreases, frequency and energy increase.
sections.content_zh:
电磁波谱是根据波长和频率排列的连续电磁波范围。所有电磁波在真空中以光速（3×10⁸米/秒）传播。

波谱包括（从最长波长到最短）：
• 无线电波 - 最长波长，最低频率
• 微波
• 红外辐射
• 可见光（红橙黄绿蓝靛紫）
• 紫外线辐射
• X射线
• 伽马射线 - 最短波长，最高频率

关键关系：波长减小时，频率和能量增加。

sections.title: Radio Waves in Astronomy and RFID
sections.title_zh: 无线电波在天文学和RFID中的应用
sections.content:
**Radio Astronomy:**
Radio telescopes detect radio waves emitted by celestial objects like stars, galaxies, and black holes. This allows astronomers to:
• Study objects invisible to optical telescopes
• Observe through dust clouds
• Detect pulsars and quasars
• Map the structure of galaxies

**RFID (Radio Frequency Identification):**
RFID tags use radio waves for automatic identification:
• Used in EZ-Link cards for MRT/bus payments in Singapore
• Library book tracking systems
• Inventory management in stores
• Access control cards
• Pet microchip identification

RFID tags contain a chip and antenna that respond to radio signals from readers.
sections.content_zh:
**射电天文学：**
射电望远镜探测恒星、星系和黑洞等天体发射的无线电波。这使天文学家能够：
• 研究光学望远镜看不见的天体
• 透过尘埃云观测
• 探测脉冲星和类星体
• 绘制星系结构图

**RFID（射频识别）：**
RFID标签使用无线电波进行自动识别：
• 在新加坡的易通卡中用于地铁/巴士支付
• 图书馆图书跟踪系统
• 商店库存管理
• 门禁卡
• 宠物微芯片识别

RFID标签包含一个芯片和天线，对读取器的无线电信号做出响应。

sections.title: Infrared and Thermal Imaging
sections.content:
**Properties of Infrared (IR) Radiation:**
• Wavelength longer than visible light but shorter than microwaves
• All objects emit infrared radiation
• Hotter objects emit more IR radiation
• Can be felt as heat

**Thermal Imaging Applications:**
1. Medical diagnosis - detecting inflammation, blood flow issues
2. Building inspection - finding heat leaks, insulation problems
3. Night vision - seeing in darkness (used by military, wildlife researchers)
4. Airport screening - detecting fever during disease outbreaks (COVID-19)
5. Electrical inspection - identifying overheating components
6. Search and rescue - locating people in darkness or smoke

**How Thermal Cameras Work:**
They detect infrared radiation emitted by objects and convert it into a visible image, with different colors representing different temperatures.
sections.content_zh:
**红外线（IR）辐射的性质：**
• 波长比可见光长但比微波短
• 所有物体都发射红外辐射
• 更热的物体发射更多红外辐射
• 可以感觉到热量

**热成像应用：**
1. 医学诊断 - 检测炎症、血流问题
2. 建筑检查 - 发现热量泄漏、绝缘问题
3. 夜视 - 在黑暗中看东西（军事、野生动物研究人员使用）
4. 机场筛查 - 在疾病爆发期间检测发烧（COVID-19）
5. 电气检查 - 识别过热部件
6. 搜救 - 在黑暗或烟雾中定位人员

**热像仪如何工作：**
它们检测物体发射的红外辐射并将其转换为可见图像，不同颜色代表不同温度。

sections.title: Effects of EM Radiation
sections.content:
**Beneficial Effects:**
• Radio waves - communication, broadcasting
• Microwaves - cooking, satellite communication
• Infrared - heating, thermal imaging, remote controls
• Visible light - sight, photosynthesis, lighting
• UV radiation - vitamin D production, sterilization
• X-rays - medical imaging, security scanning
• Gamma rays - cancer treatment, sterilizing medical equipment

**Harmful Effects:**
• UV radiation - skin burns, skin cancer, eye damage
• X-rays - cell damage, increased cancer risk with overexposure
• Gamma rays - severe radiation damage, mutations

**Safety Precautions:**
• Use sunscreen to protect from UV rays
• Limit X-ray exposure (only when medically necessary)
• Lead shielding for X-ray and gamma ray protection
• Follow radiation safety guidelines in hospitals
sections.content_zh:
**有益影响：**
• 无线电波 - 通信、广播
• 微波 - 烹饪、卫星通信
• 红外线 - 加热、热成像、遥控器
• 可见光 - 视觉、光合作用、照明
• 紫外线辐射 - 维生素D生成、消毒
• X射线 - 医学成像、安全扫描
• 伽马射线 - 癌症治疗、医疗设备消毒

**有害影响：**
• 紫外线辐射 - 皮肤灼伤、皮肤癌、眼睛损伤
• X射线 - 细胞损伤、过度暴露增加癌症风险
• 伽马射线 - 严重辐射损伤、突变

**安全预防措施：**
• 使用防晒霜保护免受紫外线
• 限制X射线暴露（仅在医学必要时）
• 铅屏蔽保护免受X射线和伽马射线
• 在医院遵循辐射安全指南

sections.title: Magnetic Fields
sections.content:
**Magnetic Field:**
• Region where magnetic force is experienced
• Represented by magnetic field lines
• Direction: from North pole to South pole
• Stronger fields have closer field lines

**Magnetic Field Around a Bar Magnet:**
• Field lines emerge from North pole
• Field lines enter at South pole
• Field lines never cross
• Strongest at the poles

**Magnetic Field Around a Current-Carrying Wire:**
• Circular field lines around the wire
• Direction given by right-hand grip rule
• Field strength increases with current
• Field strength decreases with distance

**Magnetic Field in a Solenoid:**
• Coil of wire produces strong uniform field inside
• Field pattern similar to bar magnet
• Strength increases with:
  - More turns of wire
  - Greater current
  - Iron core inserted
sections.content_zh:
**磁场：**
• 经历磁力的区域
• 由磁场线表示
• 方向：从北极到南极
• 更强的场有更近的场线

**条形磁铁周围的磁场：**
• 场线从北极出现
• 场线在南极进入
• 场线从不交叉
• 在极点处最强

**载流导线周围的磁场：**
• 导线周围的圆形场线
• 方向由右手握拳规则给出
• 场强随电流增加
• 场强随距离减小

**螺线管中的磁场：**
• 线圈在内部产生强均匀场
• 场型类似于条形磁铁
• 强度随以下因素增加：
  - 更多线圈匝数
  - 更大电流
  - 插入铁芯

sections.title: Electromagnets
sections.content:
**What is an Electromagnet?**
A coil of wire (solenoid) that becomes magnetic when current flows through it. The magnetism can be switched on and off.

**Factors Affecting Electromagnet Strength:**
1. **Number of turns** - more turns = stronger magnet
2. **Current** - larger current = stronger magnet
3. **Core material** - soft iron core makes it much stronger
4. **Core shape** - U-shaped core concentrates field

**Advantages over Permanent Magnets:**
• Can be switched on/off
• Strength can be adjusted
• Magnetic poles can be reversed
• Can be very strong

**Applications in Singapore and Worldwide:**
• MRT train door locks
• Electric bells and buzzers
• Scrapyard cranes (lifting metal)
• Circuit breakers
• Relays and switches
• Hard disk drives
• Loudspeakers
• MRI scanners in hospitals
sections.content_zh:
**什么是电磁铁？**
当电流通过线圈（螺线管）时，它会变成磁性的。磁性可以打开和关闭。

**影响电磁铁强度的因素：**
1. **匝数** - 更多匝数=更强的磁铁
2. **电流** - 更大电流=更强的磁铁
3. **芯材料** - 软铁芯使其更强
4. **芯形状** - U形芯集中场

**相对于永久磁铁的优势：**
• 可以打开/关闭
• 强度可以调节
• 磁极可以反转
• 可以非常强

**在新加坡和全球的应用：**
• 地铁列车门锁
• 电铃和蜂鸣器
• 废料场起重机（提升金属）
• 断路器
• 继电器和开关
• 硬盘驱动器
• 扬声器
• 医院的MRI扫描仪

sections.title: Electric Motors
sections.content:
**Principle:**
Electric motors convert electrical energy to kinetic energy using the motor effect (force on current-carrying wire in magnetic field).

**How a DC Motor Works:**
1. Current flows through coil in magnetic field
2. Forces act on opposite sides of coil
3. Forces cause turning effect (moment)
4. Coil rotates
5. Commutator reverses current every half turn
6. This keeps coil rotating in same direction

**Components:**
• **Coil** - carries current
• **Permanent magnets** - provide magnetic field
• **Commutator** - split ring that reverses current
• **Brushes** - maintain electrical contact

**Increasing Motor Speed:**
• Increase current
• More turns in coil
• Stronger magnets
• Better commutator design

**Applications:**
• Electric fans and air conditioners
• Electric cars and bicycles
• Washing machines and dryers
• Power tools and drills
• Computer cooling fans
• Toy cars
sections.content_zh:
**原理：**
电动机使用电动机效应（磁场中载流导线上的力）将电能转换为动能。

**直流电动机如何工作：**
1. 电流通过磁场中的线圈
2. 力作用在线圈的相对侧
3. 力产生转动效应（力矩）
4. 线圈旋转
5. 换向器每半圈反转电流
6. 这使线圈保持同一方向旋转

**组件：**
• **线圈** - 携带电流
• **永久磁铁** - 提供磁场
• **换向器** - 反转电流的分裂环
• **电刷** - 保持电接触

**增加电动机速度：**
• 增加电流
• 线圈更多匝数
• 更强的磁铁
• 更好的换向器设计

**应用：**
• 电风扇和空调
• 电动汽车和自行车
• 洗衣机和烘干机
• 电动工具和钻头
• 计算机冷却风扇
• 玩具车

sections.title: Electromagnetic Induction & Generators
sections.content:
**Electromagnetic Induction:**
Voltage is induced when:
• A conductor moves through a magnetic field, OR
• The magnetic field through a conductor changes

**Faraday's Law:**
Induced voltage increases with:
• Faster movement
• Stronger magnetic field
• More turns in coil

**Lenz's Law:**
Induced current opposes the change that caused it.

**How a Generator Works:**
1. Coil rotates in magnetic field
2. Magnetic flux through coil changes
3. Voltage induced in coil
4. Current flows in external circuit
5. Slip rings maintain continuous contact

**AC Generator produces:**
• Alternating current (changes direction)
• Sinusoidal voltage output

**Applications:**
• Power stations (turbines turn generators)
• Bicycle dynamos (wheel turns generator)
• Wind turbines
• Hydroelectric dams
• Portable generators

**Energy Conversion:**
Kinetic Energy → Electrical Energy
sections.content_zh:
**电磁感应：**
当以下情况时会感应电压：
• 导体通过磁场移动，或
• 通过导体的磁场改变

**法拉第定律：**
感应电压随以下因素增加：
• 更快的运动
• 更强的磁场
• 线圈更多匝数

**楞次定律：**
感应电流反对引起它的变化。

**发电机如何工作：**
1. 线圈在磁场中旋转
2. 通过线圈的磁通量改变
3. 在线圈中感应电压
4. 电流在外部电路中流动
5. 滑环保持连续接触

**交流发电机产生：**
• 交流电（改变方向）
• 正弦电压输出

**应用：**
• 发电站（涡轮机转动发电机）
• 自行车发电机（车轮转动发电机）
• 风力涡轮机
• 水电大坝
• 便携式发电机

**能量转换：**
动能→电能

sections.title: Electric Charge
sections.content:
**Types of Charge:**
• Positive charge (+)
• Negative charge (-)
• Neutral (equal positive and negative)

**Properties:**
• Like charges repel
• Unlike charges attract
• Charge is conserved (cannot be created or destroyed)
• Charge can be transferred

**Charging by Friction:**
When two materials are rubbed together:
• Electrons transfer from one material to the other
• Material losing electrons becomes positive
• Material gaining electrons becomes negative

**Examples:**
• Rubbing balloon on hair - balloon becomes negative
• Rubbing plastic rod with cloth - rod becomes negative
• Combing hair - comb becomes charged
sections.content_zh:
**电荷类型：**
• 正电荷（+）
• 负电荷（-）
• 中性（正负电荷相等）

**性质：**
• 同性电荷相斥
• 异性电荷相吸
• 电荷守恒（不能被创造或破坏）
• 电荷可以转移

**摩擦起电：**
当两种材料摩擦在一起时：
• 电子从一种材料转移到另一种材料
• 失去电子的材料变为正电
• 获得电子的材料变为负电

**示例：**
• 在头发上摩擦气球 - 气球变为负电
• 用布摩擦塑料棒 - 棒变为负电
• 梳头 - 梳子带电

sections.title: Main Computer Components
sections.content:
**CPU** (Central Processing Unit) is the brain - processes instructions. **RAM** (Random Access Memory) is temporary storage - holds data while computer is on.

Storage (Hard Drive/**SSD**) is permanent storage - saves files.

Motherboard connects all components. 

**Example:**

 Singapore student doing homework - **CPU **processes calculations, **RAM **holds open documents, storage saves completed work.

sections.title: Input & Output Devices
sections.content:
Input devices send data **TO **computer: Keyboard (text), Mouse (pointing), Microphone (sound), Camera (images/video), Scanner (documents).

Output devices receive data **FROM **computer: Monitor (display), Printer (paper), Speakers (sound), Headphones (audio).

Some devices are both: Touchscreen (input touch, output display), **VR **headset.

Singapore schools use interactive whiteboards - both input and output.

sections.title: How Computers Process Data
sections.content:
Input-Process-Output cycle:
1.

Input: User enters data (keyboard/mouse)
2.

Process: **CPU **executes instructions using **RAM
**3.

Output: Results displayed or saved. 

**Example:**

 Singapore student searches online - Input: Type 'Singapore history', Process: Computer sends request to Google servers, retrieves results, Output: Display search results on screen.

Everything happens in milliseconds!

sections.title: Types of Computing Devices
sections.content:
Desktop computers: Powerful, stationary, used at home/office.

Laptops: Portable, built-in screen/keyboard.

Tablets: Touchscreen, very portable (iPad, Samsung Tab).

Smartphones: Pocket-sized, always connected.

Servers: Powerful computers that provide services to many users.

Embedded systems: Computers in other devices (car, washing machine, **ATM**).

Singapore widely uses smartphones for payments, government services via Singpass app.

chapters.title: Introduction to Algorithms
chapters.description: Understanding sequences, patterns, and step-by-step instructions
chapters.description_zh: 理解序列、模式和分步指令

sections.title: What is an Algorithm?
sections.content:
Algorithm = step-by-step instructions to complete a task.

Like a recipe for cooking! 

**Example:**

 Making Milo -
1.

Boil water
2.

Put 3 spoons Milo in cup
3.

Pour hot water
4.

Stir
5.

Enjoy! Algorithms must be: Clear (no confusion), Ordered (correct sequence), Finite (must end).

Singapore traffic lights use algorithms to control light changes based on traffic flow and time.

sections.title: Sequences & Patterns
sections.content:
Sequence is ordered list: 2, 4, 6, 8 (adding 2 each time).

Pattern is repeating design: Red, Blue, Red, Blue.

Finding patterns helps solve problems faster. 

**Example:**

 Singapore bus numbers - 14, 14A, 14e follow pattern (same route, different stops).

Number patterns: 5, 10, 15, 20 (multiply by 5).

Understanding patterns is key to computational thinking.

sections.title: Breaking Down Problems
sections.content:
Decomposition means breaking big problem into smaller parts. 

**Example:**

 Planning trip to Sentosa - Big problem: 'Get to Sentosa'.

Smaller parts:
1.

Check **MRT **route
2.

Take **MRT **to HarbourFront
3.

Board Sentosa Express
4.

Choose destination station.

Each small part is easier to solve than the whole problem.

Singapore school projects often use decomposition - divide work among team members.

sections.title: Focus on What Matters
sections.content:
Abstraction means ignoring unnecessary details, focusing on important information. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **MRT **map - Shows stations and lines, but **NOT **exact distances or street names.

That's abstraction - only essential info shown.

When giving directions: 'Take Red Line to Orchard, then Green Line to Bugis' - abstract (simple).

Not: 'Travel 2.3km northeast, turn at 103.8° heading...' - too detailed.

Abstraction makes problems simpler.

chapters.title: Block-Based Programming
chapters.description: Introduction to programming using visual blocks (Scratch/Blockly)
chapters.description_zh: 使用可视化积木（Scratch/Blockly）介绍编程
objectives_zh: 使用可视化积木创建程序

sections.title: What is Block Programming?
sections.content:
Block programming uses colorful blocks instead of typing code.

Snap blocks together like **LEGO**! Popular tools: Scratch (**MIT**), Blockly (Google), Code.org.

Blocks include: Motion (move sprite), Looks (change appearance), Sound (play music), Events (when clicked), Control (if/repeat). 

**Example:**

 Make Singapore Merlion sprite move - 'When green flag clicked' + 'Move 10 steps' + 'Say Hello for 2 seconds'.

No typing errors, focus on logic!

sections.title: Sequence - Order Matters
sections.content:
Sequence = blocks run in order from top to bottom. 

**Example:**

 Singapore flag animation -
1.

Set background to red
2.

Draw white crescent
3.

Draw 5 stars
4.

Play national anthem.

If order wrong (anthem before drawing), looks strange! Programs execute one instruction at a time, in sequence.

Practice: Create program to introduce yourself -
1.

Say name
2.

Show age
3.

Say school
4.

Say hobby.

sections.title: Loops - Repetition
sections.content:
Loops repeat actions. 'Repeat 10' block runs code 10 times. 'Forever' loop runs continuously. 

**Example:**

 Draw square - Repeat 4 times: Move 50 steps, Turn 90 degrees.

Without loop, need to write same code 4 times! Singapore **EZ**-Link card tapping - Loop checks: While balance > 0, allow entry. 'Repeat until' loops until condition is true.

Use loops to avoid repetitive code.

sections.title: If-Then - Making Decisions
sections.content:
If-Then blocks make decisions.

Structure: 'If condition Then action'. 

**Example:**

 Singapore weather program - 'If temperature > 30, Say Very Hot!, Else Say Pleasant'.

Conditions use comparisons: = (equal), > (greater), < (less).

Combination: 'If raining **AND **temperature < 25, Say Cold rain'.

Singapore school attendance - 'If student present, Mark attendance, Else Send absence alert'.

Computers make millions of if-then decisions per second.

chapters.title: Digital Data & Files
chapters.description: Understanding how computers store and organize data
chapters.description_zh: 理解计算机如何存储和组织数据

sections.title: Binary - Computer Language
sections.title_zh: 二进制 - 计算机语言
sections.content:
Computers only understand 0 and 1 (binary).

Why? Electronics work with **ON** (
1. or **OFF** (0).

Bit = one binary digit (0 or 1).

Byte = 8 bits. 

**Example:**

 Letter 'A' = 01000001 in binary.

Numbers: 0=0, 1=1, 2=10, 3=11, 4=
100.

Everything in computer (text, images, videos, music) is stored as 0s and 1s! Singapore **NRIC **contains letters and numbers - all converted to binary for storage.

sections.title: Common File Types
sections.content:
Files have extensions showing type.

Documents: .docx (Word), .pdf (Adobe), .txt (plain text).

Images: .jpg/.jpeg (photos), .png (graphics with transparency), .gif (animations).

Videos: .mp4, .avi, .mov.

Audio: .mp3, .wav.

Programs: .exe (Windows).

Compressed: .zip (multiple files).

Singapore government forms often in .pdf format.

Each type needs specific program to open - can't open .docx with media player!

sections.title: Files & Folders
sections.content:
Folders (directories) organize files.

Like filing cabinet! Good structure: School/ → Math/, Science/, English/ → each has assignments/.

Path shows location: C:/Users/Student/Documents/School/Math/Homework.docx.

Root folder is top level (C: on Windows).

Use meaningful names: 'Math_Homework_Week5.docx' not 'untitled123.docx'.

Singapore students organize by subject and term for easy retrieval.

Backup important files to cloud (Google Drive, OneDrive) or external drive.

sections.title: File Sizes & Storage
sections.content:
Storage measured in bytes: Byte < **KB** (1000 bytes) < **MB** (1000 **KB**) < **GB** (1000 **MB**) < **TB** (1000 **GB**).

Text file: ~10 **KB**.

Photo: ~5 **MB**.

Song: ~5 **MB**.

Movie: ~2 **GB**.

Typical phone: 64-256 **GB **storage.

Cloud storage: Google Drive 15 **GB **free.

Large files take longer to transfer.

Singapore students submit assignments online - check file size limits (often 10-25 **MB**).

Compress large files to .zip to reduce size.

chapters.title: Internet & Online Safety
chapters.description: How the internet works and staying safe online
chapters.description_zh: 互联网如何工作以及在线安全

sections.title: How the Internet Works
sections.content:
Internet = worldwide network of connected computers.

When you visit website:
1.

Type **URL** (www.moe.gov.sg)
2.

Computer sends request through router
3.

Request travels through many routers worldwide
4.

Reaches web server
5.

Server sends webpage back to you.

All in milliseconds! **IP **address is computer's location (like postal code). **DNS **translates website names to **IP **addresses.

Singapore has excellent internet infrastructure - fast fiber broadband connections.

sections.title: Staying Safe Online
sections.content:
Online safety rules:
1.

Never share passwords
2.

Don't give personal info (**NRIC**, address, phone) to strangers
3.

Think before posting - internet is permanent
4.

Tell adult if something uncomfortable
5.

Use privacy settings on social media.

Strong passwords: 8+ characters, mix letters/numbers/symbols, different for each site. 

**Example:**

 'S1ng@p0re#2024' (but don't use this - make your own!).

Singapore Cyber Security Agency (**CSA**) provides safety resources.

sections.title: Common Online Threats
sections.content:
Cyberbullying: Mean messages, spreading rumors online - report to adults/teachers.

Phishing: Fake emails/messages trying to steal passwords - don't click suspicious links.

Malware/Viruses: Harmful software - use antivirus, don't download from untrusted sources.

Scams: Too-good-to-be-true offers - 'Win free iPhone!' likely fake.

Identity theft: Someone pretends to be you - protect personal info.

Singapore Police Force website (scamalert.sg) lists current scams to watch for.

sections.title: Your Digital Footprint
sections.content:
Digital footprint = trail of data you leave online.

Everything you post, like, share stays online - maybe forever! Future employers, schools can search your name.

Tips:
1.

Google yourself - see what others find
2.

Set social media to private
3.

Don't post anything embarrassing
4.

Be kind online - messages can be screenshot
5.

Think: Would I want teachers/parents to see this? Singapore schools emphasize positive digital citizenship. 

**Remember:**

 'What happens online, stays online.'

sections.title: Word Processing
sections.content:
Word processors create documents: Microsoft Word, Google Docs, Pages.

Features: Font styles (bold, italic, underline), Headings (Title, Heading 1, 2), Lists (bullets, numbers), Images, Tables, Spell check.

Formatting tips: Use consistent fonts, Clear headings for sections, Align text (left/center/right), Save frequently! Singapore students use Google Docs for group assignments - multiple people edit simultaneously.

Export to **PDF **for submitting assignments.

sections.title: Creating Presentations
sections.content:
Presentation software: PowerPoint, Google Slides, Keynote.

Each slide = one idea.

Good presentations:
1.

Clear title on each slide
2.

Large text (not tiny!)
3.

Few words (use images)
4.

Consistent colors/fonts
5.

Animations sparingly. 6-6 rule: Max 6 lines per slide, 6 words per line.

Singapore students present projects using slides.

Practice speaking skills - don't just read slides! Engage audience with questions, videos, demos.

sections.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets
sections.content:
Spreadsheets organize data in rows and columns: Excel, Google Sheets.

Cell = one box (A1, B2, C3).

Enter data or formulas.

Simple formulas: =A1+A2 (addition), =**SUM**(A1:A
10. (add range), =**AVERAGE**(B1:B5). 

**Example:**

 Track pocket money - Column A: Date, Column B: Amount received, Column C: Amount spent, Column D: Balance (=B-C).

Singapore students use for budgeting, science data recording, math calculations.

Charts visualize data (bar, pie, line graphs).

sections.title: Collaborating Online
sections.content:
Cloud tools enable teamwork: Google Workspace (Docs, Sheets, Slides), Microsoft 365, Zoom, Google Meet.

Share documents - multiple people edit simultaneously.

See who's editing in real-time.

Comment/suggest features for feedback.

Video calls for group discussions.

Singapore schools use Google Classroom and Microsoft Teams for online learning.

Best practices:
1.

Communicate clearly
2.

Respect others' ideas
3.

Complete your part on time
4.

Check spelling/grammar before sharing
5.

Use appropriate language and tone.

sections.title: What are Algorithms?
sections.content:
An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure to solve a problem.

Like a recipe for cooking or directions to a destination.

In computing, algorithms tell computers exactly what to do. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **MRT **route planning - finding shortest path from Jurong East to Changi Airport involves an algorithm that considers all possible routes and selects the optimal one.

sections.title: Flowchart Symbols
sections.content:
Flowcharts use standard symbols: Oval (Start/End), Rectangle (Process/Action), Diamond (Decision/Question), Parallelogram (Input/Output), Arrow (Flow direction). 

**Example:**

 **ATM **withdrawal flowchart - Check **PIN** → Verify balance → Decision: Sufficient funds? → If Yes: Dispense cash, If No: Display error.

sections.title: Pseudocode Basics
sections.content:
Pseudocode is plain language description of algorithm steps, between human language and programming code.

Uses keywords like **IF**, **THEN**, **ELSE**, **WHILE**, **FOR**, **INPUT**, **OUTPUT**.

Example for finding max of 3 numbers: **INPUT **num1, num2, num3 / **IF **num1 > num2 **AND **num1 > num3 **THEN **max = num1 / **ELSE IF **num2 > num3 **THEN **max = num2 / **ELSE **max = num3 / **OUTPUT **max

sections.title: Algorithm Efficiency
sections.content:
Efficient algorithms use fewer steps and resources.

Linear search checks each item one-by-one (slow for large lists).

Binary search divides search space in half each step (much faster for sorted lists). 

**Example:**

 Finding contact in phone with 1000 entries - Linear: up to 1000 checks, Binary: max 10 checks.

Singapore government systems process millions of transactions daily, efficiency is critical.

sections.title: Introduction to Python
sections.content:
Python is a beginner-friendly programming language used worldwide.

Created by Guido van Rossum in
1991.

Used by Google, **NASA**, Singapore government agencies.

Easy to read: print('Hello Singapore!') displays text.

Python is interpreted - runs line by line.

Case-sensitive: 'Name' and 'name' are different.

sections.title: Variables & Data Types
sections.content:
Variables store data: age = 13, name = 'Ali', height = 1.
65.

Data types: int (whole numbers), float (decimals), str (text in quotes), bool (True/False).

Python auto-detects type. 

**Example:**

 price = 5.50 (float), quantity = 3 (int), total = price * quantity (result: 16.5). 

**Singapore context:**

 gst_rate = 0.09, total_with_gst = price * (1 + gst_rate)

sections.title: Input and Output
sections.content:
output: print() displays information. print('Welcome!') or print(age).

Input: input() gets user data as string. name = input('Enter your name: ').

Convert to number: age = int(input('Enter age: ')).

Example program: Calculate **MRT **fare - distance = float(input('Distance in km: ')) / fare = 0.77 + (distance * 0.
08. / print('Fare: $' + str(fare))

sections.title: Operators in Python
sections.content:
Arithmetic: + - * / (division) // (integer division) % (remainder) ** (power). 

**Example:**

 17 % 5 = 2 (remainder).

Comparison: == (equal) != (not equal) > < >= <=.

Returns True/False. 

**Example:**

 age >= 13 checks if teenager.

Logical: and, or, not. 

**Example:**

 if age >= 13 and age <= 19 then teenager.

Singapore **PSLE **score calculation uses these operators.

sections.title: If Statements
sections.content:
if statement makes decisions: if condition: do something.

Use indentation (4 spaces). 

**Example:**

 if age >= 18: print('Can vote'). elif (else if) for multiple conditions: if score >= 75: grade = 'A' / elif score >= 60: grade = 'B' / else: grade = 'C'.

Singapore O-Level grading uses multiple conditions.

sections.title: For Loops
sections.content:
for loop repeats known number of times. range(n) generates 0 to n-
1. 

**Example:**

 for i in range(5): print(i) outputs 0,1,2,3
4. range(start, stop, step): range(1, 10
2. gives 1,3,5,7
9.

Calculate total: total = 0 / for i in range(1, 6): total = total + i / Result:
15.

Used in Singapore bus arrival times app to check next 5 buses.

sections.title: While Loops
sections.content:
while loop repeats while condition is True. 

**Example:**

 count = 1 / while count <= 5: print(count) / count = count +
1.

Use when repetitions unknown. **ATM PIN **validation: attempts = 0 / while attempts < 3: pin = input('Enter **PIN**: ') / if pin == '1234': break / attempts = attempts + 1 / else: print('Card blocked'). 

**Important:**

 ensure loop eventually ends (no infinite loops).

sections.title: Nested Structures
sections.content:
Loops and if statements can be nested (one inside another). 

**Example:**

 Print multiplication table: for row in range(1, 4): / for col in range(1, 4): / product = row * col / print(product, end=' ') / print().

Singapore class seating arrangement uses nested loops to assign seats by row and column.

sections.title: Lists in Python
sections.content:
List stores multiple values: students = ['Ali', 'Bala', 'Chen'].

Access by index (starts at 0): students[0] is 'Ali'.

Negative index from end: students[-1] is 'Chen'.

Length: len(students) =
3.

Add: students.append('Devi').

Remove: students.remove('Ali'). 

**Example:**

 Singapore **MRT **stations list - stations = ['Jurong East', 'Clementi', 'Buona Vista', 'Outram Park'].

sections.title: List Operations
sections.content:
Slicing: numbers[1:4] gets elements at index 1,2,
3. numbers[:3] first 3 elements. numbers[2:] from index 2 to end.

Concatenate: list1 + list
2.

Repeat: [0] * 5 creates [0,0,0,0,0].

Check membership: if 'Ali' in students.

Sort: numbers.sort() arranges in order.

Reverse: numbers.reverse().

Used in Singapore e-commerce sites to manage shopping cart items.

sections.title: String Manipulation
sections.content:
Strings are sequences of characters.

Access like lists: name = 'Singapore' / name[0] is 'S'.

Length: len(name) =
9.

Methods: upper(), lower(), strip(), split(), replace(). 

**Example:**

 message = '  Hello World  ' / message.strip() removes spaces = 'Hello World' / message.split() creates ['Hello', 'World'].

Check substring: if 'ore' in name (True).

Used in Singapore **NRIC **validation.

sections.title: Iterating Through Collections
sections.content:
Use for loop to process each element.

For list: for student in students: print(student).

For string: for char in 'Singapore': print(char).

With index: for i in range(len(students)): print(i, students[i]). 

**Example:**

 Calculate average - scores = [85, 92, 78, 90] / total = 0 / for score in scores: total = total + score / average = total / len(scores).

Singapore temperature monitoring system processes daily readings this way.

chapters.description: Creating reusable functions, parameters, return values, and using Python modules
chapters.description_zh: 创建可重用函数、参数、返回值和使用Python模块

sections.title: Defining Functions
sections.content:
Function is reusable block of code.

Define with def: def greet(): / print('Hello!').

Call: greet().

With parameters: def greet(name): / print('Hello ' + name + '!').

Multiple parameters: def add(a, b): / result = a + b / return result. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **GST **calculator - def add_gst(price): / gst = price * 0.09 / total = price + gst / return total

sections.title: Return Values
sections.content:
return sends value back to caller.

Function stops at return. 

**Example:**

 def max_of_two(a, b): / if a > b: return a / else: return b.

Use returned value: largest = max_of_two(10,
15. / print(largest).

Can return multiple values as tuple: def min_max(numbers): / return min(numbers), max(numbers).

Singapore grade calculator returns grade and points.

sections.title: Variable Scope
sections.content:
Local variables exist only inside function.

Global variables exist everywhere. 

**Example:**

 total = 0 (global) / def add_score(score): / total = total + score (Error! Can't modify global in function) / Use global keyword or pass as parameter.

Best practice: minimize global variables. 

**Example:**

 Singapore point-of-sale system uses local variables in each transaction function for safety.

sections.title: Python Modules
sections.content:
Module is file containing Python code you can import.

Built-in modules: math, random, datetime.

Import: import math / math.sqrt(
16. = 4.
0.

Import specific: from random import randint / dice = randint(1, 6).

Create own module: Save functions in file 'mytools.py', then import mytools.

Singapore apps use datetime module for scheduling: from datetime import datetime / now = datetime.now() / print(now.strftime('%d/%m/%Y %H:%M'))

sections.title: HTML Fundamentals
sections.content:
**HTML** (HyperText Markup Language) structures web content. Uses tags: content. Basic structure: Page Title

Main Heading

Paragraph text.

. Common tags:

-

headings,

paragraph, image, link. Singapore government websites use **HTML **for all pages.

sections.title: Semantic HTML
sections.content:
Semantic tags describe meaning: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer>.

Better than generic <div>. 

**Example:**

 Singapore school website - <header> contains logo and menu, <nav> has navigation links, <main> contains main content, <article> for news posts, <footer> for contact info.

Benefits: Accessibility (screen readers), **SEO** (search engines understand structure).

sections.title: CSS Styling
sections.content:
**CSS** (Cascading Style Sheets) makes pages beautiful. Selectors target elements. Inline:

. Internal: . External (best): . Properties: color, background-color, font-size, margin, padding, border. **Example:** Singapore flag colors - .red { background-color: #EF3340; } .white { background-color: #**FFFFFF**; }

sections.title: CSS Layout & Responsive Design
sections.content:
Box model: content, padding, border, margin.

Display: block (full width), inline (in line), flex (flexible layout).

Position: static, relative, absolute, fixed.

Responsive design adapts to screen sizes.

Media queries: @media (max-width: 600px) { /* mobile styles */ }.

Singapore government sites use responsive design for mobile access.

Flexbox example: display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;

chapters.title: Introduction to Computing
chapters.description: Understanding computers and their role in society
chapters.description_zh: 了解计算机及其在社会中的作用
objectives_zh: 识别日常生活中的计算

sections.content:
Computing is the study of how computers work and how to use them to solve problems.

Computers are everywhere in modern life - in our phones, homes, schools, and workplaces.
sections.content_zh: 计算是研究计算机如何工作以及如何使用它们解决问题。计算机在现代生活中无处不在——在我们的手机、家庭、学校和工作场所。

exercises.prompt: What is computing?
choices_zh: 研究计算机和解决问题
exercises.explanation: Computing involves understanding computers and using them to solve problems.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算涉及理解计算机并使用它们解决问题。

exercises.prompt: What is the brain of a computer called?
exercises.explanation: The CPU is the central processing unit that performs calculations and executes instructions.
exercises.explanation_zh: CPU是执行计算和指令的中央处理器。

exercises.prompt: Which of the following is an input device?
exercises.explanation: Keyboards are input devices used to enter data into computers.
exercises.explanation_zh: 键盘是用于向计算机输入数据的输入设备。

exercises.prompt: What does RAM stand for?
exercises.explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) is temporary memory used while the computer is running.
exercises.explanation_zh: RAM（随机存取存储器）是计算机运行时使用的临时存储器。

exercises.prompt: What is the difference between hardware and software?
exercises.prompt_zh: 硬件和软件有什么区别？
choices: Hardware is physical parts, software is programs and instructions
Hardware is programs, software is physical parts
choices_zh: 两者在现代计算机中都不存在
硬件是物理部件，软件是程序和指令
硬件是程序，软件是物理部件
exercises.explanation: Hardware refers to physical components you can touch, while software is the programs and instructions that run on the hardware.
exercises.explanation_zh: 硬件是指可以触摸的物理组件，而软件是在硬件上运行的程序和指令。

exercises.prompt: Which device is used to store data permanently?
exercises.prompt_zh: 哪个设备用于永久存储数据？
exercises.explanation: Hard disk drives (HDDs) or solid state drives (SSDs) store data permanently, even when the computer is turned off.
exercises.explanation_zh: 硬盘驱动器（HDD）或固态硬盘（SSD）永久存储数据，即使计算机关闭也不会丢失。

exercises.prompt: Which of the following are output devices? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是输出设备？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Monitors, printers, and speakers output information from the computer. Keyboards are input devices.
exercises.explanation_zh: 显示器、打印机和扬声器从计算机输出信息。键盘是输入设备。

exercises.prompt: What is an application software?
choices: Programs that help users perform specific tasks
choices_zh: 帮助用户执行特定任务的程序
exercises.explanation: Application software includes programs like word processors, web browsers, and games that help users accomplish specific tasks.
exercises.explanation_zh: 应用软件包括文字处理器、网络浏览器和游戏等程序，帮助用户完成特定任务。

exercises.prompt: Which of these is an example of computing in daily life in Singapore?
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪个是新加坡日常生活中计算的例子？
exercises.explanation: EZ-Link cards use computing technology to process payments for public transport in Singapore.
exercises.explanation_zh: 易通卡使用计算技术处理新加坡公共交通的付款。

exercises.prompt: What does an operating system do?
choices_zh: 管理计算机硬件和软件
exercises.explanation: Operating systems like Windows, macOS, and Linux manage all hardware and software resources on a computer.
exercises.explanation_zh: Windows、macOS和Linux等操作系统管理计算机上的所有硬件和软件资源。

exercises.prompt: Which component determines how fast a computer can process information?
exercises.prompt_zh: 哪个组件决定计算机处理信息的速度？
exercises.explanation: CPU speed, measured in gigahertz (GHz), determines how many instructions the processor can execute per second.
exercises.explanation_zh: 以千兆赫（GHz）为单位的CPU速度决定了处理器每秒可以执行多少指令。

exercises.prompt: What is the role of computers in Singapore Smart Nation initiative?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算机在新加坡智慧国家倡议中的作用是什么？
choices: Use technology to improve daily life and services
choices_zh: 使用技术改善日常生活和服务
exercises.explanation: Singapore Smart Nation uses computing and digital technology to enhance public services, healthcare, transportation, and quality of life.
exercises.explanation_zh: 新加坡智慧国家使用计算和数字技术来增强公共服务、医疗保健、交通和生活质量。

exercises.prompt: Name ONE career that requires strong computing skills.
exercises.prompt_zh: 说出一个需要强大计算技能的职业。
exercises.explanation: Many careers require computing skills, including software developers, data scientists, cybersecurity specialists, and IT professionals.
exercises.explanation_zh: 许多职业需要计算技能，包括软件开发人员、数据科学家、网络安全专家和IT专业人员。

exercises.prompt: What is the primary function of a computer network?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算机网络的主要功能是什么？
choices: Connect computers to share resources and information
choices_zh: 连接计算机以共享资源和信息
exercises.explanation: Computer networks connect multiple devices to share resources like files, printers, and internet connections.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算机网络连接多个设备以共享文件、打印机和互联网连接等资源。

exercises.prompt: Why is it important to learn computing in the 21st century?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么在21世纪学习计算很重要？
choices: Only for people who want to be programmers
Computing skills are essential for most modern careers and daily life
choices_zh: 只适合想成为程序员的人
计算技能对大多数现代职业和日常生活至关重要
exercises.explanation: Computing literacy is a fundamental skill in the digital age, needed for education, work, communication, and participating in modern society.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算素养是数字时代的基本技能，是教育、工作、交流和参与现代社会所必需的。

chapters.title: Computational Thinking
chapters.description: Problem-solving with algorithms and decomposition
chapters.description_zh: 使用算法和分解进行问题解决

sections.content: Computational thinking is a problem-solving approach that involves breaking down problems, finding patterns, and creating step-by-step solutions (algorithms).
sections.content_zh: 计算思维是一种问题解决方法，涉及分解问题、寻找模式和创建逐步解决方案（算法）。

exercises.prompt: What is computational thinking?
choices: A problem-solving approach used in computing
choices_zh: 计算中使用的问题解决方法
exercises.explanation: Computational thinking is a problem-solving process that involves decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算思维是一种问题解决过程，涉及分解、模式识别、抽象和算法。

exercises.prompt: What does decomposition mean in computational thinking?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算思维中的分解是什么意思？
choices: Breaking a complex problem into smaller, manageable parts
choices_zh: 将复杂问题分解为更小、更易管理的部分
exercises.explanation: Decomposition breaks down complex problems into smaller sub-problems that are easier to understand and solve.
exercises.explanation_zh: 分解将复杂问题分解为更容易理解和解决的小问题。

exercises.prompt: What is an algorithm?
choices: A step-by-step procedure to solve a problem
exercises.explanation: An algorithm is a finite sequence of well-defined instructions to solve a specific problem or perform a task.
exercises.explanation_zh: 算法是解决特定问题或执行任务的有限序列的明确定义的指令。

exercises.prompt: What is pattern recognition in computational thinking?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算思维中的模式识别是什么？
choices: Identifying similarities and patterns in problems
choices_zh: 识别问题中的相似性和模式
exercises.explanation: Pattern recognition involves finding similarities or patterns among problems to apply known solutions to new situations.
exercises.explanation_zh: 模式识别涉及在问题中找到相似性或模式，以将已知解决方案应用于新情况。

exercises.prompt: Arrange the steps of making a sandwich using computational thinking (decomposition):
exercises.prompt_zh: 使用计算思维（分解）安排制作三明治的步骤：
exercises.explanation: Breaking down sandwich-making into sequential steps demonstrates decomposition in computational thinking.
exercises.explanation_zh: 将制作三明治分解为连续步骤展示了计算思维中的分解。

exercises.prompt: Which of these is an example of an algorithm in daily life?
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪个是日常生活中算法的例子？
choices: A recipe with step-by-step cooking instructions
choices_zh: 带有逐步烹饪说明的食谱
exercises.explanation: A recipe is an algorithm because it provides step-by-step instructions to achieve a specific outcome (cooked food).
exercises.explanation_zh: 食谱是算法，因为它提供逐步说明以实现特定结果（煮熟的食物）。

exercises.prompt: What is abstraction in computational thinking?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算思维中的抽象是什么？
choices: Focusing on important information and ignoring irrelevant details
choices_zh: 关注重要信息并忽略无关细节
exercises.explanation: Abstraction simplifies problems by focusing on essential features and hiding unnecessary complexity.
exercises.explanation_zh: 抽象通过关注基本特征并隐藏不必要的复杂性来简化问题。

exercises.prompt: Which of these are key components of computational thinking? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是计算思维的关键组成部分？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Computational thinking includes decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms. Random guessing is not a structured approach.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算思维包括分解、模式识别、抽象和算法。随机猜测不是结构化方法。

exercises.prompt: How would you use decomposition to plan a birthday party?
exercises.prompt_zh: 你如何使用分解来计划生日派对？
choices: Break it into tasks: guest list, venue, food, decorations, entertainment
Do everything at once without planning
choices_zh: 分解为任务：宾客名单、场地、食物、装饰、娱乐
不做计划就做所有事情
exercises.explanation: Decomposition breaks the complex task of party planning into manageable sub-tasks that can be tackled individually.
exercises.explanation_zh: 分解将计划派对的复杂任务分解为可以单独处理的可管理子任务。

exercises.prompt: Write a simple algorithm to find the largest number in a list of 3 numbers. Use plain English (e.g., Step 1: ..., Step 2: ..., Step 3: ...)
exercises.prompt_zh: 写一个简单的算法来找出3个数字列表中的最大数字。使用简单的语言（例如，步骤1：...，步骤2：...，步骤3：...）
exercises.answer: Step 1: Compare first and second number. Step 2: Keep the larger one. Step 3: Compare it with the third number. Step 4: The larger one is the maximum.
exercises.explanation: This algorithm uses comparison to systematically find the maximum value by comparing pairs of numbers.
exercises.explanation_zh: 该算法通过比较数字对来系统地找到最大值。

exercises.prompt: A traffic light system uses computational thinking. Which principle is shown when the system recognizes all red lights mean stop?
exercises.prompt_zh: 交通灯系统使用计算思维。当系统识别所有红灯表示停止时，显示了哪个原则？
exercises.explanation: Recognizing that red always means stop across all traffic lights is pattern recognition - identifying a consistent rule.
exercises.explanation_zh: 识别红色在所有交通灯中总是意味着停止是模式识别——识别一致的规则。

exercises.prompt: Why is computational thinking useful outside of computing?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么计算思维在计算之外也有用？
choices: It helps solve complex problems in any field systematically
It is not useful outside computing
choices_zh: 它有助于系统地解决任何领域的复杂问题
exercises.explanation: Computational thinking is a universal problem-solving skill applicable to science, business, medicine, and everyday life.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算思维是一种通用的问题解决技能，适用于科学、商业、医学和日常生活。

exercises.prompt: Arrange these steps to create an algorithm for brushing teeth:
exercises.prompt_zh: 安排这些步骤以创建刷牙的算法：
exercises.explanation: This ordered sequence creates a clear algorithm for the daily task of brushing teeth.
exercises.explanation_zh: 这个有序序列为刷牙的日常任务创建了清晰的算法。

exercises.prompt: When designing a game, which computational thinking skill helps you identify that all levels need a start and end point?
exercises.prompt_zh: 在设计游戏时，哪种计算思维技能帮助你识别所有关卡都需要起点和终点？
exercises.explanation: Pattern recognition identifies that all game levels share common structural elements like start and end points.
exercises.explanation_zh: 模式识别识别出所有游戏关卡都有共同的结构元素，如起点和终点。

exercises.prompt: A student uses computational thinking to prepare for exams by breaking subjects into topics, finding similar question patterns, and creating a study schedule. Which skill did they NOT use?
exercises.prompt_zh: 一个学生使用计算思维通过将科目分解为主题、找到相似的问题模式并创建学习时间表来准备考试。他们没有使用哪种技能？
exercises.explanation: The student used decomposition (breaking into topics), pattern recognition (similar questions), and algorithms (study schedule), but not random guessing.
exercises.explanation_zh: 学生使用了分解（分解为主题）、模式识别（相似问题）和算法（学习时间表），但没有随机猜测。

chapters.title: Introduction to Programming
chapters.description: Basic programming concepts and sequences
chapters.description_zh: 基本编程概念和序列

sections.content:
Programming is giving instructions to computers using special languages.

Programs are sequences of commands that tell computers what to do.
sections.content_zh: 编程是使用特殊语言向计算机发出指令。程序是告诉计算机要做什么的命令序列。

exercises.prompt: What is a computer program?
choices: A set of instructions that tells a computer what to do
choices_zh: 告诉计算机做什么的一组指令
exercises.explanation: A computer program is a sequence of instructions written in a programming language that tells the computer how to perform specific tasks.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算机程序是用编程语言编写的指令序列，告诉计算机如何执行特定任务。

exercises.prompt: What is a programming language?
choices: A language used to write instructions for computers
A language spoken by programmers only
choices_zh: 用于为计算机编写指令的语言
exercises.explanation: Programming languages like Python, Java, and JavaScript allow humans to communicate instructions to computers in a structured way.
exercises.explanation_zh: Python、Java和JavaScript等编程语言允许人类以结构化的方式向计算机传达指令。

exercises.prompt: Which of these are examples of programming languages? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是编程语言的例子？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Python, Scratch, and HTML are all languages used to create computer programs. English is a human language.
exercises.explanation_zh: Python、Scratch和HTML都是用于创建计算机程序的语言。英语是人类语言。

exercises.prompt: What is a sequence in programming?
choices: Instructions executed in order, one after another
choices_zh: 按顺序一个接一个执行的指令
exercises.explanation: Sequence is one of the three basic programming constructs, where instructions are executed in the order they are written.
exercises.explanation_zh: 序列是三个基本编程结构之一，其中指令按编写顺序执行。

exercises.prompt: Arrange these instructions in the correct sequence to make a robot move forward and pick up an object:
exercises.prompt_zh: 按正确顺序排列这些指令，使机器人向前移动并拾取物体：
exercises.explanation: This sequence demonstrates the importance of instruction order in programming to achieve the desired outcome.
exercises.explanation_zh: 这个序列展示了编程中指令顺序对实现预期结果的重要性。

exercises.prompt: In Scratch, what do blocks represent?
choices: Programming commands that can be connected to create programs
choices_zh: 可以连接以创建程序的编程命令
exercises.explanation: Scratch uses visual blocks that represent programming commands, making it easier for beginners to learn programming concepts.
exercises.explanation_zh: Scratch使用代表编程命令的可视化积木，使初学者更容易学习编程概念。

exercises.prompt: What is a bug in programming?
choices: An error or mistake in the code that causes unexpected behavior
choices_zh: 代码中导致意外行为的错误或失误
exercises.explanation: A bug is an error in code that prevents the program from working as intended. The term originated from an actual moth found in early computer hardware.
exercises.explanation_zh: 错误是代码中的错误，阻止程序按预期工作。该术语源于在早期计算机硬件中发现的真正飞蛾。

exercises.prompt: What is debugging?
choices: The process of finding and fixing errors in code
choices_zh: 查找和修复代码中错误的过程
exercises.explanation: Debugging is the systematic process programmers use to identify, locate, and fix bugs in their code.
exercises.explanation_zh: 调试是程序员用来识别、定位和修复代码中错误的系统过程。

exercises.prompt: Which of these is a command a program might give to a computer?
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪个是程序可能给计算机的命令？
exercises.explanation: Computers can only execute specific, well-defined commands like displaying text, performing calculations, or storing data.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算机只能执行特定、明确定义的命令，如显示文本、执行计算或存储数据。

exercises.prompt: Name ONE visual programming language designed for beginners.
exercises.prompt_zh: 说出一种为初学者设计的可视化编程语言。
exercises.explanation: Scratch, Blockly, and similar visual programming languages use drag-and-drop blocks to teach programming concepts to beginners.
exercises.explanation_zh: Scratch、Blockly和类似的可视化编程语言使用拖放积木来向初学者教授编程概念。

exercises.prompt: Why is it important to write clear and organized code?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么编写清晰和有组织的代码很重要？
choices: So others can understand and maintain it, and to find bugs easier
choices_zh: 这样其他人可以理解和维护它，并更容易找到错误
exercises.explanation: Clear, well-organized code is easier to understand, debug, maintain, and collaborate on with other programmers.
exercises.explanation_zh: 清晰、组织良好的代码更容易理解、调试、维护，并与其他程序员协作。

exercises.prompt: What happens when you run a computer program?
exercises.prompt_zh: 运行计算机程序时会发生什么？
choices: The computer executes the instructions in the program
choices_zh: 计算机执行程序中的指令
exercises.explanation: When you run a program, the computer reads and executes each instruction in sequence to perform the intended task.
exercises.explanation_zh: 当你运行程序时，计算机读取并按顺序执行每条指令以执行预期任务。

exercises.prompt: In programming, what is input?
choices: Data or information provided to a program
choices_zh: 提供给程序的数据或信息
exercises.explanation: Input is any data or information given to a program, which can come from keyboards, mice, sensors, files, or other sources.
exercises.explanation_zh: 输入是提供给程序的任何数据或信息，可以来自键盘、鼠标、传感器、文件或其他来源。

exercises.prompt: In programming, what is output?
choices: The result or information produced by a program
choices_zh: 程序产生的结果或信息
exercises.explanation: Output is the result produced by a program after processing input, displayed on screens, printed, saved to files, or sent to other devices.
exercises.explanation_zh: 输出是程序处理输入后产生的结果，显示在屏幕上、打印、保存到文件或发送到其他设备。

exercises.prompt: What mindset should a programmer have when learning to code?
exercises.prompt_zh: 学习编程时程序员应该有什么心态？
choices: Be patient, practice regularly, and learn from mistakes
choices_zh: 要有耐心，定期练习，并从错误中学习
exercises.explanation: Successful programmers embrace challenges, learn from errors, practice consistently, and seek help when needed. Programming is a skill developed over time.
exercises.explanation_zh: 成功的程序员拥抱挑战，从错误中学习，持续练习，并在需要时寻求帮助。编程是随着时间发展的技能。

chapters.title: Data and Information
chapters.description: How computers store and represent data
chapters.description_zh: 计算机如何存储和表示数据

sections.content:
Computers store all information as binary numbers (0s and 1s).

Different types of data like numbers, text, images, and videos are all stored as binary.
sections.content_zh: 计算机将所有信息存储为二进制数（0和1）。不同类型的数据如数字、文本、图像和视频都以二进制存储。

exercises.prompt: What is data?
choices: Raw facts and figures without context
choices_zh: 没有上下文的原始事实和数字
exercises.explanation: Data consists of raw, unprocessed facts like numbers, text, images, or sounds that have not yet been given meaning.
exercises.explanation_zh: 数据由未经处理的原始事实组成，如数字、文本、图像或声音，尚未赋予意义。

exercises.prompt: What is information?
choices: Data that has been processed and given meaning
choices_zh: 已处理并赋予意义的数据
exercises.explanation: Information is data that has been processed, organized, and interpreted to provide meaning and context.
exercises.explanation_zh: 信息是已经处理、组织和解释以提供意义和上下文的数据。

exercises.prompt: Which number system do computers use internally?
exercises.prompt_zh: 计算机内部使用哪种数字系统？
exercises.explanation: Computers use binary (0s and 1s) because electronic circuits have two states: on (1) and off (0).
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算机使用二进制（0和1），因为电子电路有两种状态：开（1）和关（0）。

exercises.prompt: What does the binary digit 1 represent?
exercises.explanation: In binary, 1 represents the on state, true, or presence of an electrical signal.
exercises.explanation_zh: 在二进制中，1表示开状态、真或电信号的存在。

exercises.prompt: What is the binary number for decimal 5? (Enter as 4 digits, e.g., 0101)
exercises.prompt_zh: 十进制5的二进制数是多少？（输入4位数字，例如0101）
exercises.explanation: 5 in binary is 0101 (4+0+1). Binary uses powers of 2: 8-4-2-1.

exercises.prompt: Which of these are types of data? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是数据类型？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Text, numbers, and images are all types of data that computers can process. Emotions cannot be directly stored as data.
exercises.explanation_zh: 文本、数字和图像都是计算机可以处理的数据类型。情感不能直接作为数据存储。

exercises.prompt: How many bits are in one byte?
exercises.explanation: A byte consists of 8 bits and can represent 256 different values (2^8).
exercises.explanation_zh: 一个字节由8位组成，可以表示256个不同的值（2^8）。

exercises.prompt: Which file format is used for images?
exercises.prompt_zh: 哪种文件格式用于图像？
exercises.explanation: JPEG and PNG are common image file formats. MP3 is for audio, DOCX for documents, and EXE for executable programs.
exercises.explanation_zh: JPEG和PNG是常见的图像文件格式。MP3用于音频，DOCX用于文档，EXE用于可执行程序。

exercises.prompt: What is a database?
choices: An organized collection of data stored electronically
choices_zh: 以电子方式存储的有组织的数据集合
exercises.explanation: A database is a structured collection of data that can be easily accessed, managed, and updated.
exercises.explanation_zh: 数据库是可以轻松访问、管理和更新的结构化数据集合。

exercises.prompt: Match each file extension with its data type:
exercises.prompt_zh: 将每个文件扩展名与其数据类型匹配：
exercises.explanation: Different file extensions indicate different types of data: .txt for text, .jpg for images, .mp3 for audio, .mp4 for video.
exercises.explanation_zh: 不同的文件扩展名表示不同类型的数据：.txt表示文本，.jpg表示图像，.mp3表示音频，.mp4表示视频。

exercises.prompt: Why is data important in the digital age?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么数据在数字时代很重要？
choices: It helps us make informed decisions and understand patterns
choices_zh: 它帮助我们做出明智的决定并理解模式
exercises.explanation: Data analysis helps businesses, governments, and individuals make better decisions based on evidence and patterns.
exercises.explanation_zh: 数据分析帮助企业、政府和个人根据证据和模式做出更好的决定。

exercises.prompt: What happens when you convert data from one format to another (e.g., Word to PDF)?
exercises.prompt_zh: 当你将数据从一种格式转换为另一种格式（例如Word到PDF）时会发生什么？
choices: The data is transformed but the information content remains
choices_zh: 数据被转换但信息内容保持不变
exercises.explanation: Format conversion changes how data is stored and displayed, but preserves the underlying information.
exercises.explanation_zh: 格式转换改变了数据的存储和显示方式，但保留了底层信息。

exercises.prompt: What is metadata?
choices: Data about data (e.g., file size, creation date, author)
choices_zh: 关于数据的数据（例如文件大小、创建日期、作者）
exercises.explanation: Metadata provides information about other data, such as when a file was created, who created it, its size, and format.
exercises.explanation_zh: 元数据提供有关其他数据的信息，例如文件何时创建、谁创建的、大小和格式。

exercises.prompt: Name ONE unit used to measure data storage size that is larger than a byte.
exercises.prompt_zh: 说出一个比字节大的用于测量数据存储大小的单位。
exercises.explanation: Common data storage units from smallest to largest: Byte, Kilobyte (KB), Megabyte (MB), Gigabyte (GB), Terabyte (TB).
exercises.explanation_zh: 常见的数据存储单位从小到大：字节、千字节（KB）、兆字节（MB）、吉字节（GB）、太字节（TB）。

exercises.prompt: How does Singapore use data in its Smart Nation initiative?
exercises.prompt_zh: 新加坡如何在智慧国家倡议中使用数据？
choices: To improve services like transport, healthcare, and urban planning
choices_zh: 改善交通、医疗保健和城市规划等服务
exercises.explanation: Singapore collects and analyzes data from sensors, apps, and services to optimize traffic flow, healthcare delivery, and city operations.
exercises.explanation_zh: 新加坡从传感器、应用程序和服务中收集和分析数据，以优化交通流、医疗保健交付和城市运营。

chapters.title: Networks and the Internet
chapters.description: How computers connect and communicate
chapters.description_zh: 计算机如何连接和通信

sections.content:
Computer networks allow devices to connect and share information.

The Internet is a global network connecting billions of devices worldwide.
sections.content_zh: 计算机网络允许设备连接和共享信息。互联网是连接全球数十亿设备的全球网络。

exercises.prompt: What is a computer network?
choices: A group of computers connected together to share resources
choices_zh: 连接在一起以共享资源的一组计算机
exercises.explanation: A computer network connects multiple devices to share data, resources like printers, and internet connections.
exercises.explanation_zh: 计算机网络连接多个设备以共享数据、打印机等资源和互联网连接。

exercises.prompt: What is the Internet?
choices: A global network of interconnected computers
exercises.explanation: The Internet is a worldwide network that connects billions of devices, allowing them to communicate and share information.
exercises.explanation_zh: 互联网是连接数十亿设备的全球网络，允许它们交流和共享信息。

exercises.prompt: What does WWW stand for?
exercises.explanation: WWW (World Wide Web) is a system of interlinked documents and resources accessed via the Internet using web browsers.
exercises.explanation_zh: WWW（万维网）是通过使用网络浏览器通过互联网访问的相互链接的文档和资源系统。

exercises.prompt: Which of these devices can connect to a network? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些设备可以连接到网络？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Modern devices like smartphones, laptops, and smart TVs can all connect to networks. A pencil is not an electronic device.
exercises.explanation_zh: 智能手机、笔记本电脑和智能电视等现代设备都可以连接到网络。铅笔不是电子设备。

exercises.prompt: What is Wi-Fi?
choices: A wireless technology for connecting devices to networks
choices_zh: 用于将设备连接到网络的无线技术
exercises.explanation: Wi-Fi is a wireless networking technology that allows devices to connect to the internet and each other without physical cables.
exercises.explanation_zh: Wi-Fi是一种无线网络技术，允许设备在没有物理电缆的情况下连接到互联网和彼此。

exercises.prompt: What is an IP address?
choices: A unique identifier for devices on a network
choices_zh: 网络上设备的唯一标识符
exercises.explanation: An IP (Internet Protocol) address is a numerical label assigned to each device on a network, like a digital address.
exercises.explanation_zh: IP（互联网协议）地址是分配给网络上每个设备的数字标签，就像数字地址。

exercises.prompt: What is a web browser?
choices: Software used to access and view websites
choices_zh: 用于访问和查看网站的软件
exercises.explanation: Web browsers like Chrome, Safari, Firefox, and Edge allow users to access and navigate websites on the Internet.
exercises.explanation_zh: Chrome、Safari、Firefox和Edge等网络浏览器允许用户访问和浏览互联网上的网站。

exercises.prompt: What is a URL?
choices: The address of a website (e.g., www.example.com)
exercises.explanation: URL (Uniform Resource Locator) is the address used to access resources on the Internet, like website addresses.
exercises.explanation_zh: URL（统一资源定位符）是用于访问互联网上资源的地址，如网站地址。

exercises.prompt: What is online safety?
choices: Practices to protect yourself and your information on the Internet
choices_zh: 在互联网上保护自己和信息的做法
exercises.explanation: Online safety includes protecting personal information, using strong passwords, and being cautious about suspicious links and downloads.
exercises.explanation_zh: 在线安全包括保护个人信息、使用强密码以及对可疑链接和下载保持谨慎。

exercises.prompt: Which of these are good online safety practices? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是良好的在线安全做法？（选择所有适用项）
choices: Do not share personal information with strangers
choices_zh: 不要与陌生人分享个人信息
exercises.explanation: Good online safety includes strong passwords, protecting personal information, and being cautious. Never share passwords with others.
exercises.explanation_zh: 良好的在线安全包括强密码、保护个人信息和保持谨慎。永远不要与他人分享密码。

exercises.prompt: What is email?
choices: Electronic mail for sending messages over the Internet
choices_zh: 通过互联网发送消息的电子邮件
exercises.explanation: Email is a method of exchanging digital messages over the Internet, much faster than traditional postal mail.
exercises.explanation_zh: 电子邮件是通过互联网交换数字消息的方法，比传统邮政邮件快得多。

exercises.prompt: How has the Internet changed communication in Singapore?
exercises.prompt_zh: 互联网如何改变了新加坡的沟通？
choices: Enabled instant messaging, video calls, and easy access to information
choices_zh: 消除了所有面对面的互动
实现了即时消息、视频通话和轻松访问信息
exercises.explanation: The Internet revolutionized communication in Singapore through apps like WhatsApp, Zoom, and social media, enabling instant global connectivity.
exercises.explanation_zh: 互联网通过WhatsApp、Zoom和社交媒体等应用程序彻底改变了新加坡的沟通，实现了即时的全球连接。

exercises.prompt: Name ONE social media platform used in Singapore.
exercises.prompt_zh: 说出一个在新加坡使用的社交媒体平台。
exercises.explanation: Popular social media platforms in Singapore include Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, WhatsApp, and others.
exercises.explanation_zh: 新加坡流行的社交媒体平台包括Facebook、Instagram、TikTok、WhatsApp等。

exercises.prompt: What is cloud storage?
choices: Storing files on Internet servers instead of local devices
choices_zh: 在互联网服务器上存储文件而不是本地设备
exercises.explanation: Cloud storage services like Google Drive, Dropbox, and iCloud store your files on remote servers accessible from any device with Internet.
exercises.explanation_zh: Google Drive、Dropbox和iCloud等云存储服务将您的文件存储在可以从任何有互联网的设备访问的远程服务器上。

exercises.prompt: Why is Internet connectivity important for modern society?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么互联网连接对现代社会很重要？
choices: It enables education, work, communication, and access to services
choices_zh: 它使教育、工作、沟通和访问服务成为可能
exercises.explanation: Internet connectivity is essential for online learning, remote work, telemedicine, e-government services, and staying connected globally.
exercises.explanation_zh: 互联网连接对于在线学习、远程工作、远程医疗、电子政务服务和保持全球联系至关重要。

chapters.title: Digital Citizenship and Ethics
chapters.description: Responsible use of technology
chapters.description_zh: 负责任地使用技术

sections.content:
Digital citizenship means being responsible, respectful, and safe when using technology.

This includes protecting personal information and respecting others online.
sections.content_zh: 数字公民意味着在使用技术时负责任、尊重他人和安全。这包括保护个人信息和在线尊重他人。

exercises.prompt: What is digital citizenship?
choices: Responsible and ethical behavior when using technology
choices_zh: 使用技术时负责任和道德的行为
exercises.explanation: Digital citizenship means using technology safely, responsibly, and ethically while respecting others online.
exercises.explanation_zh: 数字公民意味着在尊重他人的同时安全、负责任和道德地使用技术。

exercises.prompt: What is cyberbullying?
choices: Using technology to harass, threaten, or hurt others
choices_zh: 使用技术骚扰、威胁或伤害他人
exercises.explanation: Cyberbullying is online harassment that can cause serious harm. It is never acceptable and should be reported.
exercises.explanation_zh: 网络欺凌是可能造成严重伤害的在线骚扰。这永远不可接受，应该被举报。

exercises.prompt: Which actions demonstrate good digital citizenship? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 哪些行为展示了良好的数字公民？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Good digital citizenship includes kindness, privacy protection, and reporting harmful behavior. Spreading rumors is harmful.
exercises.explanation_zh: 良好的数字公民包括友善、隐私保护和举报有害行为。散布谣言是有害的。

exercises.prompt: What is intellectual property?
choices: Creations of the mind like inventions, art, and writing
choices_zh: 创造性作品，如发明、艺术和写作
exercises.explanation: Intellectual property includes creations like music, books, software, and inventions that are protected by copyright and patents.
exercises.explanation_zh: 知识产权包括音乐、书籍、软件和发明等受版权和专利保护的创作。

exercises.prompt: What is plagiarism?
choices: Using someone else work or ideas without giving credit
choices_zh: 使用他人的作品或想法而不给予信用
exercises.explanation: Plagiarism is stealing someone work and presenting it as your own. Always cite sources and give credit to original creators.
exercises.explanation_zh: 抄袭是窃取他人的作品并将其作为自己的作品呈现。始终引用来源并给予原创者信用。

exercises.prompt: What is copyright?
choices: Legal protection for original creative works
choices_zh: 对原创作品的法律保护
exercises.explanation: Copyright gives creators exclusive rights to their original works like books, music, videos, and software.
exercises.explanation_zh: 版权赋予创作者对其原创作品（如书籍、音乐、视频和软件）的专有权。

exercises.prompt: What should you do if you witness cyberbullying?
exercises.prompt_zh: 如果你目睹网络欺凌应该怎么做？
choices: Report it to an adult or authority
exercises.explanation: If you witness cyberbullying, report it to a trusted adult, teacher, or platform moderator to help stop the harmful behavior.
exercises.explanation_zh: 如果你目睹网络欺凌，向值得信赖的成人、教师或平台管理员报告，以帮助停止有害行为。

exercises.prompt: What is ONE way to create a strong password?
exercises.prompt_zh: 创建强密码的一种方法是什么？
exercises.answer: Use a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols
exercises.explanation: Strong passwords include a combination of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special symbols, and are at least 8-12 characters long.
exercises.explanation_zh: 强密码包括大小写字母、数字和特殊符号的组合，长度至少为8-12个字符。

exercises.prompt: What is personal data?
choices: Information that can identify you (name, address, phone, photos)
choices_zh: 可以识别你的信息（姓名、地址、电话、照片）
exercises.explanation: Personal data includes any information that can identify you, such as your name, address, photos, and online activity.
exercises.explanation_zh: 个人数据包括可以识别你的任何信息，例如你的姓名、地址、照片和在线活动。

exercises.prompt: Which of these are examples of personal information you should protect online? (Select all that apply)
exercises.prompt_zh: 以下哪些是你应该在线保护的个人信息的例子？（选择所有适用项）
exercises.explanation: Home address, passwords, and phone numbers are sensitive personal information. Favorite color is generally safe to share.
exercises.explanation_zh: 家庭地址、密码和电话号码是敏感的个人信息。最喜欢的颜色通常可以安全分享。

exercises.prompt: What is the purpose of the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) in Singapore?
exercises.prompt_zh: 新加坡个人数据保护法（PDPA）的目的是什么？
choices: To allow companies to share all data freely
To protect individuals personal data and regulate how organizations collect and use it
choices_zh: 允许公司自由分享所有数据
保护个人的个人数据并规范组织如何收集和使用它
exercises.explanation: Singapore PDPA protects personal data by setting rules for how organizations must collect, use, and protect your information responsibly.
exercises.explanation_zh: 新加坡PDPA通过为组织必须如何负责任地收集、使用和保护您的信息设定规则来保护个人数据。

exercises.prompt: What is screen time?
choices: The amount of time spent using digital devices
choices_zh: 使用数字设备花费的时间
exercises.explanation: Screen time refers to time spent on phones, tablets, computers, TVs, and other digital devices. Balanced screen time is important for health.
exercises.explanation_zh: 屏幕时间是指在手机、平板电脑、计算机、电视和其他数字设备上花费的时间。平衡的屏幕时间对健康很重要。

exercises.prompt: What should you do before sharing a photo or post online?
exercises.prompt_zh: 在线分享照片或帖子之前应该做什么？
choices: Think about who can see it and if it could hurt anyone
choices_zh: 考虑谁可以看到它以及它是否会伤害任何人
exercises.explanation: Before posting, think about privacy, whether content is appropriate, and how it might affect you and others. Once online, content can be hard to remove.
exercises.explanation_zh: 在发布之前，考虑隐私、内容是否适当以及它可能如何影响你和他人。一旦在线，内容可能很难删除。

exercises.prompt: Name ONE consequence of excessive screen time.
exercises.prompt_zh: 说出过度使用屏幕的一个后果。
exercises.explanation: Excessive screen time can lead to eye strain, poor sleep, reduced physical activity, poor posture, and decreased face-to-face social interaction.
exercises.explanation_zh: 过度使用屏幕可能导致眼睛疲劳、睡眠不良、减少身体活动、姿势不良和面对面社交互动减少。

exercises.prompt: Why is it important to be a responsible digital citizen?
exercises.prompt_zh: 为什么成为负责任的数字公民很重要？
choices: To create a safe, respectful, and positive online environment for everyone
choices_zh: 为每个人创造一个安全、尊重和积极的在线环境
exercises.explanation: Responsible digital citizenship makes the Internet safer and more positive for everyone by promoting respect, kindness, and ethical behavior online.
exercises.explanation_zh: 负责任的数字公民通过在线促进尊重、友善和道德行为，使互联网对每个人都更安全、更积极。
